questions.text: The refractive index is the maximum at which of the following surface:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Centre of the lens The relaxed eye has an approximate optical power of 60 diopters (D) (ie, its focal length is 16.7 mm in air), with the corneal power being about 40 D or two-thirds of the total power.

Highyeild:

The crystalline lens of the eye, located behind the iris, is composed of specialized crystallin proteins with a refractive index of n=1.40-1.42. The lens is about 4 mm in thickness and 10 mm in diameter and is enclosed in a tough, thin (5-15 mm), transparent collagenous capsule.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . Due to the orderly arrangement of collagen fibrils in the cornea, it is highly transparent with transmission above 95% in the spectral range of 400-900 nm. Option: B . The refractive index of the cornea is n≈1.3765±0.0005. The amount of light reaching the retina is regulated by the pupil size, which can vary between 1.5 mm and 8 mm. Option: C . The anterior chamber of the eye , which is located between the cornea and lens capsule, is filled with a clear liquid––the aqueous humor having a refractive index n≈1.3335.

Extraedge:

In the relaxed eye, the lens has a power of about 20 D , while in the fully accommodated state, it can temporarily increase to 33 D. The vitreous humor ––a transparent jelly-like substance filling the large cavity posterior to the lens and anterior to the retina––has a refractive index n≈1.335.

questions.text: Asteroid hyalinosis is composed of which of the following:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Calcium Histologically, asteroid bodies are rounded structures that stain positively with alcian blue and positively with stains for neutral fats, phospholipids, and calcium. The bodies stain metachromatically and exhibit birefringence . Occasionally, asteroid bodies will be surrounded by a foreign body giant cell , but the condition is not generally associated with vitreous inflammation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Iron - Calcium is the correct option. Option: B. Copper - this is not the correct option. Option: D. Silica - this is incorrect.

questions.text: What should not be done to this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Removal of foreign body Because removal of FB causes a reduction in IOP which is important for maintaining the nutrition of the eye as well as texture The intraocular foreign body is classified into Toxic can be due to metallic iron/steel/ nickel/copper/aluminum/ mercury/ zinc Non metallic vegetative material Inert may be due to Metallic gold, silver, platinum Non-metallic carbon, stone, porcelain, rubber Modes of damage - Mechanical effects - depending upon size and velocity

Highyeild:

Introduction of infection - metallic FB are usually sterile Pieces of wood or stone Reactions to FB Inert FB - no reaction Lead & aluminum cause fibrosis Zinc, copper, aluminum, and merc- incite suppuration Siderosis - degenerative changes by iron FB due to electrolytic dissociation and dissemination The earliest sign - of deposition in the anterior capsule of the lens appearing as a rusty ring is pathognomonic Heterochromia iridis hyperchromic

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . Visual loss due to pigmentary retinal dystrophy Secondary glaucoma Diagnosed by Prussian blue reaction Chassis - copper from an alloy deposited on a membranous structure Option: C . Kaiser- Fleischer ring - deposition in descemet's membrane in Wilson a disease Sunflower cataract No degenerative changes hence visual prognosis is good Option: D . Caterpillar hair produces granulomatous iridocyclitis known as ophthalmia nodosa

Extraedge:

Management- CT scan is IOC for metallic FB MRI is CI for metallic FB Forceps removal with or without pars plana vitrectomy

questions.text: Identify the instrument depicted in the given Image:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Synoptophore A haploscope is an optical device for presenting one Image to one eye and another Image to the other eye. The word is often used interchangeably with stereoscope , but it is more general than that. A stereoscope is a type of haploscope, but not vice versa. The word has more currency in the medical field than elsewhere, where it refers to instruments designed to test binocular vision. These instruments include Worth's amblyoscope and the synoptophore . Commonly laparoscopic employ front-surface mirrors placed at different angles close to the eyes to reflect the Images into the eyes.

Highyeild:

Reputedly the largest haploscope, with Images of over a meter (in fact, 4 feet) square and a viewing distance for each eye of nearly five meters (16 feet), was The large images allowed very small retinal disparities to be presented. B. Perimeter C. Tonometer D. Operating microscope

questions.text: Identify the pathology depicted in the given Image:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Telecanthus Telecanthus, or dystopia canthorum, refers to the increased distance between the inner corners of the eyelids (medial canthi), while the inter-pupillary distance is normal. This is in contrast to hypertelorism, in which the distance between the whole eyes is increased. The average interpupillary distance is 60–62 mm , which corresponds to an intercanthal distance of approximately 30–31 mm Associated with systemic conditions such as Down syndrome, fetal alcohol syndrome, cri du Chat syndrome, Klinefelter syndrome, Turner syndrome, Ehlers–Danlos syndrome, Waardenburg syndrome

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B. Pterygium Option C. Distichiasis Option D. Ectropion

questions.text: Which of the following does not handle free radicals in lenses?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

VIT. A The ocular lens , which is continually exposed to light and ambient oxygen, is at high risk of photooxidative damage resulting in cataracts.

Highyeild:

Oxygen free radicals appear to impair not only lens crystallins which will aggregate and precipitate forming opacities but also proteolytic enzymes whose function would be to eliminate the damaged proteins.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B, C, and D . Apart from an enzymatic defense system consisting of superoxide dismutase, catalase, and glutathione peroxidase against excited oxygen species the lens contains the antioxidant vitamins C, E, and presumably β-carotene as another line of defense

questions.text: A 59-year-old man comes to the physician because of bilateral blurry vision and difficulty driving at night that has been worsening progressively over the past 5 months. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. His hemoglobin A1c concentration is 8.9 mg/dL. A slit lamp shows cloudy opacities of the lenses bilaterally. The patient's eye condition is most likely due to increased activity of which of the following enzymes?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aldose Reductase This patient's physical examination shows bilateral cataracts , most likely due to his poorly-controlled diabetes mellitus. Aldose reductase catalyzes the reduction of glucose to sorbitol , which is subsequently oxidized to fructose by the sorbitol dehydrogenase enzyme. At normal blood glucose levels, only a small part of glucose is metabolized via this polyol pathway.

Highyeild:

In chronic hyperglycemia due to poorly controlled diabetes , sorbitol formation increases significantly, causing osmotic damage in tissues with low sorbitol dehydrogenase activity (e.g., lens, retina, kidney, and myelin sheath). Consequently, patients present with retinopathy, nephropathy, peripheral neuropathy, and bilateral cataracts as seen in this patient.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Galactokinase catalyzes the conversion of galactose to galactose-1-phosphate. Deficiency of this enzyme, not overactivation, causes mild galactosemia (galactokinase deficiency), resulting in cataract formation due to the accumulation of galactitol in the lens of the eye. Option: B. Aldolase B is predominantly expressed in the liver and converts fructose-1-phosphate to dihydroxyacetone phosphate (DHAP) and glyceraldehyde. No specific pathologic condition has been associated with the overactivity of this enzyme. Its deficiency does however result in hereditary fructose intolerance, which typically presents with hypoglycemia ( due to inhibition of glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis) and vomiting following consumption of fructose-containing food. Option: C. Sorbitol dehydrogenase converts sorbitol into fructose, which can be used as an energy substrate in the liver and seminal vesicles. The activity of this enzyme is low in the retina and lens.

Extraedge:

During chronic hyperglycemia , sorbitol can accumulate in these tissues, causing bilateral cataracts as seen in this patient. However, increased activity of this enzyme is not associated with any specific pathologic conditions.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for a blurry vision for the past 2 months. He is at the 97th percentile for height and the 25th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows joint hypermobility, a high-arched palate, and abnormally long, slender fingers and toes. Slit lamp examination shows superotemporal lens subluxation bilaterally. This patient's findings are most likely caused by a defect in which of the following structural proteins?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fibrillin This patient presents with features of Marfan syndrome (i.e., tall stature, high-arched palate, arachnodactyly, joint hypermobility, and superotemporal lens subluxation). Marfan syndrome is caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in the fibrillin-1 gene, which encodes fibrillin, an extracellular matrix glycoprotein that forms a supportive sheath around elastin.

Highyeild:

Abnormal elastin production leads to defective connective tissue and excessive growth factor release. Further features of Marfan syndrome include vascular abnormalities (e.g., aortic aneurysm or dissection).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Defective laminin can cause junctional epidermolysis bullosa, a condition characterized by fragile skin that easily blisters. This patient's symptoms cannot be explained by a defect in laminin. Option: B. Defective type III collagen is the cause of vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which presents primarily with cardiovascular manifestations. These include heart valve defects (especially mitral valve prolapse), aneurysms or dissections of large arteries (e.g., aortic, iliac), and berry aneurysms of cerebral arteries. This patient's symptoms cannot be explained by a defect in type III collagen. Option: C. Defective keratin can cause epidermolysis bullosa simplex, a condition characterized by fragile skin that easily blisters. This patient's symptoms cannot be explained by a defect in keratin
